text: By the way, if you need to figure out your current path, use os.getcwd().
You can change the working directory with os.chdir( path ).
There are two best practices to follow:

code:
class Chdir:         
      def __init__( self, newPath ):  
        self.savedPath = os.getcwd()
        os.chdir(newPath)

      def __del__( self ):
        os.chdir( self.savedPath )

text: Note that this snippet assumes that self.savedPath is still valid.
Improving the handling of this is an exercise left up to the programmer.
Changing the current working directory in a subprocess does not change the current working directory in the parent process.
This is true of the Python interpreter as well.
You cannot use os.chdir() to change the CWD of the calling process.
If you're using a relatively new version of Python, you can also use a context manager, such as this one:

code:
from __future__ import with_statement
from grizzled.os import working_directory

with working_directory(path_to_directory):
    # code in here occurs within the directory

# code here is in the original directory
